channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Distracted Russia Is Losing Its Grip on Its Old Soviet Sphere
item.description: Russia’s domination of Central Asia and the Caucasus region is unraveling as the Kremlin focuses on the war in Ukraine — and border violence is flaring.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Russia names a new commander for the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Pavel Golovkin/Associated Press

item.title: How Insurers Exploited Medicare Advantage for Billions
item.description: By next year, half of Medicare beneficiaries will have a private Medicare Advantage plan. Most large insurers in the program have been accused in court of fraud.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

item.title: How Trump Deflected Repeated Demands to Return Documents
item.description: The former president exhibited a pattern of dissembling about the material he took from the White House, creating legal risk not just for himself but also some of his lawyers.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump spent a year and a half deflecting demands from the federal government to return documents.

item.title: In Trump Case, Texas Creates a Headache for Georgia Prosecutors
item.description: A Texas court is thwarting Georgia prosecutors’ attempts to compel testimony from Texas witnesses as part of a criminal investigation into former President Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sidney Powell, one of President Donald Trump’s election lawyers, is one of three Texas witnesses who have not appeared for court dates in Atlanta that are part of an investigation into the former president and his allies.

item.title: How Team Dietitians Are Changing How Baseball Players Eat
item.description: With each team required to have a dietitian on staff, the days of pizza, hot dogs and nachos are largely over.
item.dc:creator: Adam Elder
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times

item.title: Herschel Walker Urged Woman to Have a 2nd Abortion, She Says
item.description: The Georgia Senate candidate’s ex-girlfriend says he wanted her to terminate a pregnancy in 2011. She chose to have their son instead.
item.dc:creator: Maya King, Lisa Lerer and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Nicole Buchanan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Herschel Walker, speaking at a campaign stop in Wadley, Ga., on Thursday, did not address a report that he had paid for a woman’s abortion.

item.title: Fetterman’s Blue-Collar Allure Is Tested in Pennsylvania Senate Race
item.description: John Fetterman, the Democratic nominee for Senate, says he can win over working-class voters in deep-red counties. Some evidence suggests he can, but partisan loyalties may prove more powerful.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Justin Merriman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman at an event on Wednesday in Murrysville, Pa. For much of his Senate race against Mehmet Oz, he has held a sizable lead in the polls, but the contest has tightened.

item.title: Many of Hurricane Ian’s Victims Were Older Adults Who Drowned
item.description: The storm, Florida’s deadliest since 1935, has been linked to the deaths of at least 119 people in the state, many of them older residents who lived near the coast.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith, Frances Robles, Eliza Fawcett and Ava Sasani
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Search-and-rescue workers combed Fort Myers Beach, Fla., last week after Hurricane Ian’s destructive landfall.

item.title: As New York’s Fear of Crime Grows, a Neighborhood Lives With Its Reality
item.description: Cypress Hills in Brooklyn is among the areas that lead the city in serious crimes. Krystal Chimelis is looking for a way out.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Krystal Chimelis feels hemmed in by violence at home and priced out of other parts of New York.

item.title: How to Surf on the East Coast
item.description: Autumn may be the season of big swells, but the smaller waves found year-round near East Coast cities are perfect for beginners who want to give surfing a try.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Fogarty
item.media:credit: Yuvraj Khanna for The New York Times

item.title: Donald Trump and Herschel Walker: The Unholy Alliance
item.description: Republicans sink to a new low in defending Walker.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Ben Gray/Associated Press

item.title: A Lost Manuscript Shows the Fire Barack Obama Couldn’t Reveal on the Campaign Trail
item.description: At Harvard Law, he wrote a blistering manifesto he never published. Its searing advice could help Democrats escape their current political quagmire.
item.dc:creator: Timothy Shenk
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Wonking Out: A Jobs Survey Full of Good News
item.description: There are reasons for optimism about inflation.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by MmeEmil and Prasit photo via Getty Images

item.title: A Language Test That Stigmatizes Black Children
item.description: Black English is not slang. It is a dialect with clear rules and structure.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter
item.media:credit: Delcan and Co.

item.title: Xi Jinping Is the Second Coming of Mao Zedong
item.description: He would consider that a compliment. It’s not.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; image by Zenobillis via Getty Images

item.title: The N.Y.U. Chemistry Students Shouldn’t Have Needed That Petition
item.description: High-stakes weed-out classes like organic chemistry are relics of an age when college students were much more uniformly privileged.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Calarco
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times

item.title: ‘It’s Like a War Out There.’ Iran’s Women Haven’t Been This Angry in a Generation.
item.description: The gap between the freedoms and opportunities enjoyed by the system’s affiliated elite and those of ordinary Iranians has never been so wide.
item.dc:creator: Azadeh Moaveni
item.media:credit: Richard Tomkins/Associated Press
item.media:description: Iranian women demonstrating for equal rights in 1979.

item.title: Democrats Can’t Afford to Lose Nevada
item.description: A loss in the race for Senate could change the direction of the country on major public policy issues.
item.dc:creator: Jon Ralston
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times

item.title: Page Turners
item.description: Fall is the perfect time to hunker down and read deeply.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Where defending nature can be deadly
item.description: No region is more dangerous for environmentalists than Latin America. We explain why it’s getting worse.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Ueslei Marcelino/Reuters
item.media:description: Indigenous land defenders detained a logger in Brazil, by many measures the world’s most dangerous country for environmental activists, in 2019.

item.title: The Sudden Rise of Zach Bryan
item.description: The breakout country-folk singer and songwriter has found an audience for his old-fashioned artistry largely on a newer platform: streaming.
item.media:credit: Kristin Braga Wright for The New York Times

item.title: Have You Changed How You Shop and Where You Dine? We Want to Hear About It.
item.description: Higher food prices are changing people’s behaviors at the grocery store and in restaurants. Let us know how they have affected you.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Celeste Noche for The New York Times
item.media:description: A trip to the grocery store is more expensive than it was two years ago.

item.title: In California, One Hardy Pine Tree Has Survived for 4,800 Years
item.description: In a harsh alpine desert, the Great Basin bristlecone pines abide amid climate change. Among them is the oldest tree on Earth (if you can find it).
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla and Adam Perez

item.title: After Secret US Talks Fail, A Hidden War in Africa Rapidly Escalates
item.description: Months of discreet American diplomacy have failed to stop the fighting in northern Ethiopia. Now, the civil war is plunging into its most alarming phase yet.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh

item.title: A Yayoi Kusama Pumpkin Sculpture Is Reinstalled in Japan
item.description: Technically, it’s a replica of the polka-dot plastic creation that was damaged by a storm last year. But regardless, people are happy.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives

item.title: How a Scottish Moral Philosopher Got Elon Musk’s Number
item.description: In a few short years, effective altruism has become the giving philosophy for many Silicon Valley programmers, hedge funders and even tech billionaires.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish

item.title: For Some Breast Cancer Survivors, October Is the Cruelest Month
item.description: Pink ribbons can be a tough reminder for many breast cancer survivors. Here’s how to make it easier.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Breast cancer is 365 days a year, not 31,” said Bri Majsiak, who co-founded a nonprofit organization for people impacted by breast and gynecological cancers.

item.title: What is E.M.D.R.? Understanding the Trauma Therapy Practice
item.description: The once-experimental trauma treatment has become increasingly popular. Here’s how the therapy works.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Sophie Park
item.category: The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind and Body in the Healing of Trauma (Book)
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: How to Meditate When You Can’t Sit Still
item.description: Closing your eyes and focusing on breathing can be hard for those who are easily distracted. But it is possible.
item.dc:creator: A.C. Shilton
item.media:credit: Francesco Ciccolella

item.title: Burnout vs Depression: How to Tell the Difference and Find Relief
item.description: Clinicians and researchers offer advice on how to tell the difference, and what to do about both.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: The Facts and Fictions of Shostakovich’s ‘Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk’
item.description: The 1934 opera, revived this season at the Metropolitan Opera, stoked the ire of the Soviet state, or so the story goes. But archives tell a more interesting tale.
item.dc:creator: Simon Morrison
item.media:credit: via Nemirovich-Danchenko Theater
item.media:description: The 1934 production of Shostakovich’s “Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk” in Moscow at the Nemirovich-Danchenko Theater, where the work took on the title “Katerina Izmailova.”

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
